author: LatinoMuyFinO
body:
Some Options:

BYND Calls: I shorted this today from $138 to $135. Could have made more if i had held til close but fuck it. They took a beating and am expecting a bounce back from the 132-133 level. I'll be going short term calls tomorrow for a quick scalp at open.

PTON Calls: Same as above \^ bounce back from the $40-41 level

DKNG: FOMO if you want. This thing could pop to $40 or drop to $30. I won't be touching this until at least another week or so. Risky af but mad tendiez if you guess the right direction (calls/puts)

COTY: Same as above, but I expect this will hold better than DKNG since its already near rock bottom prices. Might throw a few thousand at it tomorrow in calls.

SPY: i personally don't play SPY, but there is mad tendiez to be made if you get in calls at a dip (around the 295-297 range) or puts (around the 301-303 range).

CCL, RCL, NCLH: Easy plays to go long on a dip, Beaten up cruise stocks that have been forming new bottoms. Easy 2x 3x bagger if you get in before a large move up in the premarket. They seem a bit overheated lately though so I would be careful of a pullback soon, in which case go short term puts.

AAL, DAL, UAL, LUV, SAVE: Same as above

AAPL, MSFT, AMD, NVDA: Tech saw a big hit today, might be a good spot to buy the dip. I'll be watching closely tomorrow if we continue to fall in tech at open, then I'm buying the dip for sure.

BABA, TSM: GYNA stocks if you want i guess

&#x200B;

Good luck making your parents money back you fucking autist.

author: pervsensei11
body:
I don’t know who needs to hear this but consistent small profits > high risk diamond hand plays.

I’m up 120% past week but down down 22% overall.

Was up 177% in March but got greedy and took a huge hit and was too stubborn to close positions.

Some suggestions for newbie autists/ people who have no idea what they’re doing and just playing roulette 

- I close positions if I’m up 40% on the play (played NVIDIA TESLA AND SPY past week) every single play would have been a loss if I held during a mid day crash that happened this week

- don’t go all in with all your capital on single play and if you do always hedge a small position to stay solvent Eg. You’re buying weekly spy calls with 50/60% of your capital buy monthly VIX calls as well as a hedge in case there is a sudden mid day crash that rolls over to next day your hedge will keep you solvent or make bank depending on how it plays out and VIX options are generally very cheaper compared to SPY options

- this one should be a no brainer but don’t be stubborn and hold a bad play for too long, if you made a 2k investment on SPY contracts and it dips beyond 30%, either open a small hedge position or close your positions and take a one day break to reset. 1.4k capital is better than a full 2k loss.

That’s all folks, thanks for coming to my Ted talk and good luck tomorrow. Let’s get them tendies

author: introspective_lemon
body:
100% the main thing OP is missing is the software aspect. Nvidia isn’t just a “chip” company anymore. I saw their latest GTC keynote and most of it was covering their various SDKs and tools for various markets (DL, robotics, autonomous vehicles, graphics).

Granted, I see both Intel and AMD getting a foothold into some of these markets as well. I think it’s the case that all of them can “win” and compete with Nvidia by offering more open solutions at lower cost. But it’s going to be a challenge for them for sure.

author: PillarsBliz
body:
I think it's an interesting question since I am familiarizing myself with companies.  Surely companies won't have their share price increase forever (just look at the crash this year), but some of the ones I expect will still be strong in 6 months would be:

* NVDA (despite the recent crash I think they'll at least stay strong, they have a good product, and they're in good financial shape)
* HD (I want to trade this, seems a very solid company for contractor / do it yourself / home install stuff)
* BBY (of all the consumer stores besides maybe Wal-mart, this seems in the best financial shape to survive?)
* DIS (Disney has been tremendously successful at adapting and surviving, and I expect their stock to recover hugely)
* MSFT (huge company, seems to be in good shape, if they die then we're in deep trouble everywhere since Windows is so ubiquitous)
* KO (good defensive stock, decent dividend)

If I had more money, I'd probably look at Apple, Amazon, and Tesla.

author: caedin8
body:
What you are missing is NVDA's economic moat in the machine learning world. 

All the software runs on CUDA. The software stack that enables the AI revolution is what is going to put NVDA products in every data center for the ongoing future.

I am a machine learning engineer and everything I use runs on CUDA. Being the backbone behind the AI revolution over the next 10 years is going to be extremely profitable for NVDA, just like the Windows OS made Microsoft the biggest home computer company, and iOS made Apple the biggest phone company.

author: SaneLad
body:
I'm afraid this comment is greatly out of date. NVDA crashed the second half of 2018 when altcoin market caps imploded by 90%+ forcing the retail miner to accept the fact that small-scale mining on GPUs is wildly unprofitable.

The NVDA growth since then has all been about machine learning. (They are also not doing that well with consumer GPUs btw, they have been losing a lot of technological ground to the competition.)

author: DARPA1191969v1
body:
I can give the perspective from a tech/software dev.

In my opinion, these are sort of different players. In fact, I would say that NVDA and AMD are far more analogous to each other than even AMD -> AAPL, and certainly to MSFT. The  way that I see it, NVDA/AMD are fundamentally companies that are concerned with producing a *physical good* \- literal chipsets and dies. AAPL seems to waver on the hardware side of things (they have been known to go proprietary in that arena, but have also loaned out work to INTC on more than one occasion). I most certainly see MSFT as a true software/PaaS/SaaS company - suffice to say that they are producing very little in the way of physical goods.

I think the *soft/hardware* direction is important to mention, because that fundamentally plays into the way that these companies deal in the market. Developing hardware is a mind-bendingly expensive process (relatively speaking). It takes years of R&D and cash on hand to fund something that is truly great. An example of this would be the move AMD made to Zen (which is based on the concept of 'chiplets'; highly-scalable many-core designs that are fundamentally different from their monolithic predecessors).

In terms of growth, I would have to say that I see two viable options here: *NVDA and MSFT*. MSFT is pretty easy to explain; they create a product that fundamentally has lower upstart costs (software development's most expensive attribute is the cost of human labor) and lower maintenance costs (I would think). There is some movement towards a more data-center driven profit scheme (which would require boots on ground hardware en masse), and Azure is certainly an AWS competitor, but I think we've yet to see them really go full throttle on that (I think it could be big if they did).

NVDA is a leader from a technological perspective. GPU compute-cores are very specialized devices that are good at doing only a few things, but very, *very well.* NVDA has been hammering away at this technology for years - they know the game, and they know where the money is. Autonomous cars, drones...the computer viz recogition software for postal, for literally anything, runs on a platform that is fundamentally a GPU (very high level view here). Machine learning applications in this field at the data-center level (think machine learning on AWS) are absolutely dominated by NVDA; In fact I would go as far as to say there aren't really a lot of competitors out there that are bringing to the table what NVDA does (Honestly AMD has severely gimped even their consumer dies at this point).

&#x200B;

I can elaborate more, but I'd go with MSFT and NVDA on this one.

author: ApartheidClyde
body:
Been thinking hard and long about whats going on.

I think i figured it out. Its the indirect manipulation of stonks by putting a floor under corporate credit regardless of their financial situation. It doesnt matter what company you are, you are protected by a whale who controls the market.

This guy thinks the same - 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2WMJyBLVxEk&t=1s

Essentially this pump will only end with total destruction of Fed. And only thing that can bring it down is Fx markets.

There are 2 ways for stonks to go up - improve earnings or devalue the dollar. Fed seems to be doing the latter. 

During a recession, stonks go down and old companies die giving way to new. Now Fed is saying, we will keep stonks pumped up even during a recession so boomers need not sell their 401k's. Thats why LULU and CMG and NVDA are at ATH even with consumer spending crashing.

author: BigEd781
body:
>The reason for this is that most blue chips nowadays have already had there Impressive growth

Have you calculated how many years of growth at X% are already baked into the price of a single share of AMD? I'm not saying AMD is a bad investment, I like AMD as a company quite a bit, but I would hope you understand how to project earnings, relate that to share price, and evaluate that in the context of their current P/E. 

You're about to put a lot of money on something I don't think you've quite thought through.

>comparable companies to amd like Nvidia have a stock prices in the hundreds

Completely irrelevant. If I told you I'd sell you 1/10 of my company for $1, or 1/20 for $0.50, what's the difference?

author: Best_Of_The_Midwest
body:
This is not a good theta gang trade. It's a terrible risk/reward trade off. You would typically want the credit to be at least 1/3rd the width of the strikes. 

For example, I sold an NVDA iron condor last week that looks like this: 

https://imgur.com/melXw7c

$1000 risk for $325 in premium. Not saying this trade will be a winner, but it's a much better trade than OP's.
